case_name: Bar Council of U.P. v. State of U.P.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1971 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 9, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 143 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated July 9, 1970 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 143 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 9, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 143 of 1964.

facts.text: Petition filed by Bar Council of U.P. under Art. 226 challenging amendments in Art. 30 of Schedule 1-B of Indian Stamp Act by U.P. Stamp Amendment Acts from 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GROVER, J. This appeal by special leave against a judgment of the Allahabad High Court arises out of a petition filed by the Bar Council of U.P. under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the amendments made in Art. 30 of Schedule 1-B of the Indian Stamp Act by the U.P. Stamp  Amendment  Acts from 1962 onwards.

facts.text: Advocates Act 1961 enacted by Indian Parliament and published in Government of India Gazette dated May 19, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The points which arise for determination ate of some importance to the persons belonging to the legal profession. The Advocates Act 1961, hereinafter called the Act was enacted by the Indian Parliament and was published in the Government of India Gazette dated May 19, 1961.

facts.text: Notification dated August 7, 1961 fixed August 16, 1961 as date for provisions of Chapters I, II and VII of Advocates Act to come into force.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated August 7, 1961 the Central Government fixed August 16, 1961 as the date on which the provisions of Chapters 1, 11 and VII of the Act were to companye into force.

facts.text: Bar Council of U.P. was constituted after notification dated August 7, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Bar Council of U.P. was companystituted thereafter.

facts.text: Notification dated November 24, 1961 brought Chapter III of Advocates Act into force.

anchor.surface_text: Another numberification was issued on November 24, 1961 by the Central Government bringing into, force Chapter III of the Act with immediate effect.

facts.text: Appointed day for Advocates Act is December 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: immediately before the appointed date, i.e. December 1, 1961.

facts.text: Under s.24(1)(f) of Advocates Act, State Bar Council entitled to admit person as advocate on payment of Rs. 250 fee if qualifications fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 24  1    f   of the Act the State Bar Council was entitled to admit a person as an advocate on its roll if he paid a fee of Rs. 250/provided he fulfilled the qualifications prescribed by that section.

facts.text: U.P. Stamp Amendment Act 1962 amended Art. 30 making additional Rs. 500 stamp duty payable on entry as advocate on State roll of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: But by reason of the amendment of Art. 30 by the U.P. Stamp Amendment Act 1962 an additional sum of Rs. 500/- became payable, as stamp duty on the entry as an advocate on the State roll of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1969 brought into force by notification dated September 13, 1969 with effect from October 1, 1969, amended Article 30 retrospectively, stamp duty Rs. 500 on certificate under s.22.

anchor.surface_text: The next amendment was made by the State Legislature by enacting the Uttar Pradesh Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1969 which was brought into force by a numberification dated September 13, 1969 with effect from October 1, 1969. Clause 3 of S. 3 of the Amendment Act of 1969 amended Article 30 of the Act.

facts.text: Indian Stamp U.P. Amendment Act 1970 substituted clause (c) in s.11(1), inserted Art.17A in Schedule 1-B for Rs. 250 stamp duty on certificate under s.22, omitted Article 30.

anchor.surface_text: The latest amendment was made by the Indian Stamp  U.P. Amendment  Act 1970 in s. 11 1 of the Indian Stamp Act 1077 as amended in its application to U.P. for clause  c  the following clause was substituted Certificate of enrolment under S. 22 of the Advocates Act, 1961, issued by the State Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Learned single judge allowed writ petition by judgment dated November 12, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge who heard the writ petition filed by the Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh allowed the same by a judgment dated November 12, 1963.

facts.text: Division Bench allowed special appeal and set aside single judge judgment.

anchor.surface_text: A special appeal against the judgment of the single judge was taken to a Division Bench. After referring to the various entries in the three lists it was held that numberquestion of repugnancy arose between the Stamp Amendment Acts and the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Under Bar Council Act 1926 s.8, fee of Rs.10 payable to Bar Council for enrolment.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that such persons shall have paid in respect of enrolment the stamp-duty, if any, chargeable under the Indian Stamp Act, 1899, and a fee, payable to the Bar Council, which shall be ten rupees in the case of the persons referred to in clause  a  and in other cases such amount as may be prescribed.

facts.text: Stamp duty payable under Art.30 Schedule 1-B Indian Stamp Act as amended in U.P. on entry on roll of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the entry on the roll of the High Court the stamp duty was payable under Art. 30 of Schedule 1-B of the Indian Stamp Act as amended in U.P.

facts.text: All India Bar Committee appointed prior to 1953 made recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to 1953 an All India Bar Committee was appointed which made recommendations in 1953 after taking into account the recommendation of the Law Commission on the subject of role of judicial administration in so far as the recommendation related to the Bar and to legal education.

facts.text: Under s.18 Advocates Act, transfer of name from one State Bar Council roll to another without payment of any fee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 laid down that any person whose name was entered as an advocate on the roll of any State Bar Council companyld make an application to the Bar Council of India for the transfer of his name from the roll of that State Council to the roll of any other State Bar Council.

facts.text: Petitioner argued levy discriminatory because advocates in other states pay only Rs.250 enrolment fee, while in UP Rs.250 plus stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: Discrimination was stated to arise in two ways  i  An advocate in one State has to pay only the enrolment fee of Rs. 250/ and numbermore, whereas, in Uttar Pradesh, he has to pay number only Rs. 250/- as enrolment fee but also a stamp duty as prescribed by the Stamp Amendment Act

facts.text: Petitioner argued discrimination in transfer: pay duty for transfer to UP but not to other states without duty.

anchor.surface_text: and  ii  when an advocate whose name is borne on the roll of the Bar Council of a State, where numberduty is leviable on the certificate of enrolment, wishes to get his name transferred to the roll of the Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh lie shall have to pay the duty prescribed by the Stamp Amendment Act

facts.text: Court held State Legislature competent to levy stamp duty under Entry 63 List II and Entry 44 List III.

anchor.surface_text: The imposition of such a duty falls in pith and substance under Entry 44 of List III and the prescribing of rates under Entry 63 of List 11.

facts.text: Assent of President obtained for impugned U.P. Amending Acts complying with Art.254(2).

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case, the provisions of Art. 254 2  have been companyplied with inasmuch as the assent of the President had been taken while enacting the impugned Amending Act.

facts.text: Single judge held State encroached on Parliament's field by levying stamp duty not prescribed in Advocates Act.

anchor.surface_text: He was of the view that it was within the exclusive companypetence of the Parliament to legislate in respect of persons entitled to practise before the Supreme Court and the High Courts and the State Legislatures had numbersuch companypetence.

facts.text: Division Bench held no repugnancy as Stamp Acts received President's assent under Art.254(2).

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that numberquestion of repugnancy companyld arise under Art. 254 of the Constitution because the Stamp Amendment Laws had received the companysideration of the President and his assent and thus the companyditions laid down by Art. 254 2  had been companyplied with.

facts.text: Supreme Court approved Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras, I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 933.

anchor.surface_text: Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras, I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 933, approved.

This appeal by special leave against a judgment of the Allahabad High Court arises out of a petition filed by the Bar Council of U.P. under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the amendments made in Art. 30 of Schedule 1-B of the Indian Stamp Act by the U.P. Stamp  Amendment  Acts from 1962 onwards.

concepts.unlisted_description: Legislative competence under Union, State, Concurrent lists.

issues.text: whether the provision made by the State Legislature for imposition of duty on the certificate of enrolment to be issued by the State Bar Council is invalid and unconstitutional in view of the provision in the Act which prescribes a fee of Rs. 250/- only for enrolment as an advocate.

anchor.surface_text: The question which was agitated before the High Court and which has been raised before us is whether the provision made by the State Legislature for imposition of duty on the certificate of enrolment to be issued by the State Bar Council is invalid and unconstitutional in view of the provision in the Act which prescribes a fee of Rs. 250/- only for enrolment as an advocate.

issues.text: whether the levy of stamp duty on the certificate of enrolment of an advocate is a purely taxation measure or whether it is a part of the conditions prescribed by s. 24 of the Act which an advocate must satisfy before he becomes entitled to practise.

anchor.surface_text: The main question on which the controversy has centered is whether the levy of stamp duty on the certificate of enrolment of an advocate is a purely taxation measure or whether it is a part of the conditions prescribed by s. 24 of the Act which an advocate must satisfy before he becomes entitled to practise.

issues.text: Whether there is repugnancy under Art. 254 of the Constitution between the impugned Stamp Amendment Acts and the Advocates Act.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that power to tax was within the competence of the State Legislature no question of repugnancy under Art. 254 of the Constitution could arise. A question of repugnancy can only arise in matters where both Parliament and State Legislature have legislative competence to pass laws, that is, when the legislative power is located in the Concurrent List.

issues.text: Whether the levy of stamp duty is discriminatory under Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the argument that the levy is discriminatory. Discrimination was stated to arise in two ways (i) An advocate in one State has to pay only the enrolment fee of Rs. 250/ and no more, whereas, in Uttar Pradesh, he has to pay not only Rs. 250/- as enrolment fee but also a stamp duty as prescribed by the Stamp Amendment Act

arguments.claim: No question of repugnancy under Art. 254 as tax power is within State competence, not concurrent list.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that power to tax was within the competence of the State Legislature no question of repugnancy under Art. 254 of the Constitution could arise. A question of repugnancy can only arise in matters where both Parliament and State Legislature have legislative competence to pass laws, that is, when the legislative power is located in the Concurrent List.

arguments.claim: Provisions of Art. 254(2) complied with as President's assent obtained for impugned acts.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case, the provisions of Art. 254 (2) have been complied with inasmuch as the assent of the President had been taken while enacting the impugned Amending Act.

arguments.claim: Levy of stamp duty is discriminatory because advocates in other states pay only Rs.250 enrolment fee, but in UP Rs.250 plus stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: Discrimination was stated to arise in two ways (i) An advocate in one State has to pay only the enrolment fee of Rs. 250/ and no more, whereas, in Uttar Pradesh, he has to pay not only Rs. 250/- as enrolment fee but also a stamp duty as prescribed by the Stamp Amendment Act,

arguments.claim: Levy discriminatory because transfer to UP requires stamp duty but transfer to other states without duty does not.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 14 can have no application where the sources of authority of the Parliamentary and State legislation are different.

arguments.claim: State Legislature encroached on Parliament's exclusive legislative field under Entries 77 and 78 List I by levying stamp duty, as Act comprehensively deals with enrolment conditions including Rs.250 fee and omits stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: He was of the view that it was within the exclusive competence of the Parliament to legislate in respect of persons entitled to practise before the Supreme Court and the High Courts and the State Legislatures had no such competence. ... the State Legislature had, by levying stamp duty on such a certificate, encroached on the legislative field of Parliament.

arguments.court_reasoning: Stamp duty falls under Entry 44 List III and rates under Entry 63 List II.

arguments.claim: No repugnancy between Stamp Acts and Advocates Act as President's assent obtained under Art.254(2).

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that no question of repugnancy could arise under Art. 254 of the Constitution because the Stamp Amendment Laws had received the consideration of the President and his assent and thus the conditions laid down by Art. 254 (2) had been complied with.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cated in the Concurrent List. Moreover, in the present case, the provisions of Art. 254 2  have been companyplied with inasmuch as the assent of the P

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees President's assent complies with Art.254(2).

arguments.claim: Imposition of stamp duty falls in pith and substance under Entry 44 List III and rates under Entry 63 List II.
Stamp duty on enrolment certificate is purely taxation measure, not a condition prescribed by s.24 of Advocates Act for entitlement to practise.

anchor.surface_text: The main question on which the controversy has centered is whether the levy of stamp duty on the certificate of enrolment of an advocate is a purely taxation measure or whether it is a part of the conditions prescribed by s. 24 of the Act which an advocate must satisfy before he becomes entitled to practise.

arguments.claim: Under previous Bar Council Act 1926 s.8, stamp duty was expressly required in addition to fee.

anchor.surface_text: It has been pointed out on behalf of the respondents that the Indian Bar Council Act 1926 was passed under the provisions of the Government of India Act 1915. ... expressly saying that the persons who were to be enrolled as advocates shall have to pay stamp duty, if any, chargeable under the Indian Stamp Act 1899 and fee payable to the Bar Council.

arguments.court_reasoning: Historical context supports separation of fee and stamp duty.

arguments.claim: Advocates Act does not occupy field or bar levy of stamp duty, no provision exempting stamp duty.
Levy of stamp duty on enrolment certificate valid as per Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras, I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 933, approved.

arguments.claim: Art.14 does not apply to discriminate between Parliamentary and State legislation from different sources.

anchor.surface_text: But Art. 14 can have no application where the sources of authority of the Parliamentary and State legislation are different.

arguments.claim: State stamp duty provision invalid as Parliament prescribed only Rs.250 fee in s.24(1)(f), deliberately omitting stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: The question which was agitated before the High Court and which has been raised before us is whether the provision made by the State Legislature for imposition of duty on the certificate of enrolment to be issued by the State Bar Council is invalid and unconstitutional in view of the provision in the Act which prescribes a fee of Rs. 250/- only for enrolment as an advocate.

arguments.court_reasoning: Taxation separate from conditions of enrolment.

holdings.text: Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras, I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 933, approved.

anchor.surface_text: Ananthakrishnan v. State of Madras, I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 933, approved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent holding state taxing power over stamp duty on enrolment documents followed and approved.

holdings.text: Once it is held that power to tax was within the competence of the State Legislature no question of repugnancy under Art. 254 of the Constitution could arise. A question of repugnancy can only arise in matters where both Parliament and State Legislature have legislative competence to pass laws, that is, when the legislative power is located in the Concurrent List.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that power to tax was within the companypetence of the State Legislature numberquestion of repugnancy under Art. 254 of the Constitution companyld arise. A question of repugnancy can only arise in matters where both Parliament and State Legislature have legislative companypetence to pass laws, that is, when the legislative power is located in the Concurrent List.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repugnancy arises only when both legislatures competent in concurrent field; stamp duty rates under exclusive state List II power.

holdings.text: Moreover, in the present case, the provisions of Art. 254 (2) have been complied with inasmuch as the assent of the President had been taken while enacting the impugned Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case, the provisions of Art. 254 2  have been companyplied with inasmuch as the assent of the President had been taken while enacting the impugned Amending Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: President's assent obtained, satisfying Art.254(2) for any potential repugnancy.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the argument that the levy is discriminatory... But Art. 14 can have no application where the sources of authority of the Parliamentary and State legislation are different.

anchor.surface_text: There is nosubstance in the argument that the levy is discriminatory. Discrimination was stated to arise in two ways  i  An advocate in one State has to pay only the enrolment fee of Rs. 250/ and numbermore, whereas, in Uttar Pradesh, he has to pay number only Rs. 250/- as enrolment fee but also a stamp duty as prescribed by the Stamp Amendment Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 14 inapplicable to legislation from different sources (Parliament vs State); follows State of Madhya Pradesh v. G. C. Mandawar.

holdings.text: The imposition of such a duty falls in pith and substance under Entry 44 of List III and the prescribing of rates under Entry 63 of List II.

anchor.surface_text: The imposition of such a duty falls in pith and substance under Entry 44 of List III and the prescribing of rates under Entry 63 of List 11.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying doctrine of pith and substance, stamp duty is taxation not enrolment condition; state competent under concurrent charging (List III) and exclusive rates (List II).

holdings.text: It is difficult to escape the conclusion that the levy of stamp duty by means of the Stamp Amendment Acts in the State of Uttar Pradesh was not covered by any of the Entries in List I and therefore it could not be said that the State was incompetent to levy the duty and prescribe the rate under Entry 44 of List III and Entry 63 of List II in the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to ,escape the companyclusion that the levy of stamp duty by means of the Stamp Amendment Acts in the State of Uttar Pradesh was number companye by any of the Entries in List I and therefore it companyld number be said that the State was incompetent to levy the duty and prescribe the rate under Entry 44 of List III and Entry 63 of List II in the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advocates Act under List I Entries 77/78 excludes tax; no field occupation barring state stamp tax; argument of incompetence repelled.

holdings.text: The stamp duty which is payable on the certificate of enrolment pertains to the domain of taxation and it is hardly possible to regard it as a condition which can be prescribed for enrolment under the Entries in List I.

anchor.surface_text: The main question on which the companytroversy has centered is whether the levy of stamp duty on the certificate of enrolment of an advocate is a purely taxation measure or whether it is a part of the companyditions prescribed by s. 24 of the Act which an advocate must satisfy before he becomes entitled to practise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes fee under s.24 (List I Entry 96) from tax (List III/ II); historical separation under prior acts supports.

holdings.text: Any argument on the basis of legislative incompetence, has, therefore, to be repelled.

anchor.surface_text: Any argument on th basis of legislative incompetence, has, therefore, to be repelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State competent; no encroachment on Parliament's field.

holdings.text: In order to achieve uniformity it is for the States to refrain from levying any stamp duty on the certificates of enrolment or for Parliament to enact proper legislation so as to do away with a feature which is certainly derogatory to the ultimate aim and goal of the Act of having a common Bar for the whole country with uniformity in all material respects.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on policy for uniformity under Advocates Act aims; not binding.

outcome.relief_summary: Challenge to validity of U.P. Stamp Amendment Acts rejected; State Legislature competent to levy stamp duty on certificates of enrolment issued by State Bar Council under Advocates Act
directions: In order to achieve uniformity it is for the States to refrain from levying any stamp duty on the certificates of enrolment or for Parliament to enact proper legislation so as to do away with a feature which is certainly derogatory to the ultimate aim and goal of the Act of having a common Bar for the whole country with uniformity in all material respects.
